Choices:  A: disorientation B: due to C: meeting new people D: getting somewhere E: relocation<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer to the question is "D: getting somewhere," as in order to travel underwater one must relocate to the underwater environment. This means that they would therefore have low visibility causing a change in environment that is due to relocation.<n><n>### Examples of correct responses:<n><n>### Example 1<n><n>**Input:** There would be lots of people going to work on the metro yesterday if there wasn't a what? Choices: A: strike B: closure C: interruption D: lockdown E: halt<n><n>**Demostration:** We get the idea from the title and question that there was an event that happened. From this, we are certain that people would be able to complete their work if not for something like a lockdown (a type of closure). Therefore, the correct answer must be "D: a lockdown."<n><n><n>### Example2<n><n>**Demosntration:** We know that an incentive is something that motivates people, and that it is a cause of an increase in productivity. Furthermore, we are told that an incentive can be monetary or non-monetary. In the first statement, the answer is a "gift" which is therefore non-monetary and a reason for an increase in productivity, which is therefore an incentive of the first kind: one that raises efficiency. Hence, the correct choice is "A: gift of time." <n><n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### 1. A gift of time would have the properties of an incentive or cause a cause of an increase production.<n><n>### 2. The next statement indicates that an incentive of either kind can result in an increase in productivity<n><n>### 3. A gift of time does not have to be monetary. Hence, it is a non-monetary incentive.<n><n><n>### 4. "A gift of time increases productivity" would be incomplete if there weren't an antecedent that implied a cause-and-effect relationship.<n><n>### Example3<n><n>**Input: **While they were away, the student spent hours every day making what? Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: stay here<n><n>### Demos:<n>I do not know John. I am making up his answers for the question. It is a fantasy or a future scenario where the narrator (me) is imagining him in his future.<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:John moved away from hi family.  He was bit upset that he ha to do it, but  he needed the job.Still, would have prefered it if the job were where? I do not know that he can choose nothig else.<n><n>E:come here-John has not choice to do that because he can not not work where he is living.<n><n>Answer: B: stay here<n><n>

The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If an animal is tired, what is it likely to do? Choices:  A: bite B: lie down C: keep alive D: need to eat E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: C: keep alive<n><n>### Instructor Recommended Response:<n>Answer: D: need to eat<n><n>### Demystified: The question tells us that animals are likely to do one of a few activities when they are tired. This leads us to the conclusion that either "keep alive" or "keeping alive", which is essentially synonymous to "staying alive", is a possible answer.<n><n>If we compare the "keep alive" answer to "need to" answer, they are both grammatically correct and do fit the context, but it turns out "keep alive" actually makes the most sense. "Need" in this context would mean that there is a requirement for them to keep "alive". Without the negative context of "do not" in "don't need", the implication is that an animal _would_ need to keep "alive" no matter how tired or exhausted they are. On the other hand, "keep alive" means that the animal could be alive but in a passive manner without consciously maintaining their life. Thus, "keep alive" is the logical answer.<n><n>### Answer to Demystified:<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Instructions: Answers the following multiple choice question and provides a statement that uses the response you have identified as the correct answer.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>The sentence has three parts. A:The reason we must remember not to take a drink to bed is B: Because sleeping will make us 1) less sleepy and 2) more alert. C: We'll be more alert if we stay awake, and we'll be less alert if we sleep.<n> <n>Answer: B: Because sleeping, though not impossible, will make us tired from using our energy and less sleepy and more alert.<n><n><n><n>The sentence has three clues. A: "The reason we must remember" indicates that there is a why we need not to take a drink. B: "not to take a drink to sleep will make us less sleepy and more awake and alert" is a hint that we should not take a drink to bed. C: "Stay awake and we will be more alert" indicates that if we take a drink to bed, there will be consequences. The clues are: A B C<n><n>From clues A and C, the

"use soap" can not be an activity of the obsessive man.<n>- "even done it so much once." "use soap" once is so hard for obsessive man to do.

Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>The Indian Ocean is located in Asia, and is bounded by Asian countries such as India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and more. Therefore the correct answer is A: asia.<n><n>### Inputs:What does the abbreviation NT mean on a map? Choices:  B: north T: timeline E: end F: new G: night<n><n>### Response<n><n>Looking at the abbreviation on a map, we see that the letters N and T are capitalized, while the letters E and R are in a different typeface, both of which are common in modern typography (Capitals for main terms, lowercase for qualifiers). This suggests that the abbreviation could be similar to terms like GEO, TURTLE, or REX, that have initial capitals and a lowercase abbreviation. The NT would be a similar abbreviation for "New Year."<n><n>The closest reasonable option would be "night," which is written NITE, and the closest match that doesn't look too bizarre would be NIGHT.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Looking closely at the other options, there are no reasonable N-word combinations in which the abbreviation NT is in all uppercase letters, with a different typeface from the qualifying E and R, which are lowercase. Hence, the correct option is NIGHT.<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>What does the abbreviation AE mean on a map?<n><n>### Answer:<n>On a map, the abbreviation AE is used to indicate the date on which something in question was established, usually a day. Therefore, the correct answer is: A, on a map, AE means a date on which something was established.<n><n>

Choices:  A: go to bed B: sleep C: listen to music D: stretch out E: stop worrying<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Output:<n>A: go to bed<n><n>### Demolishion:<n><n>### Justification:<n>The passenger put on his headphone to relax in response to the other passengers on the bus being loud. By looking at the answer choice "go to bed," it is possible to rule out other common activities such as listening to music, stretching and stopping worrying, as the answer refers to "putting on" the headphones, suggesting that the other passengers were loud before the passenger put on headphones. <n>Thus, "go to bed" is the only choice that makes logical sense in the context of the problem.<n>

We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. Choices:  A: orchestra B: school band C: music store D: opera house E: home<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: When would you be able to see your cousin in person? Choices: A: next month B: last month C: tomorrow D: last week E: 2 days before last week<n>Rationales: There are two parts to this question: an inference and a calculation.<n><n>- The inference: We need to establish when your cousin's birthday is based on the information given in the problem: "you can see your cousin 2 days before his birthday". "2 days before his birth" means it is in the past. When is your cousin's birth? "2 days before" means it is not the actual day of the birthday, and "before" means you need to count backwards. This means your cousin's birth is on the day before "2 days". So to find out when is that birthday you need to subtract two days from the actual date. In the example question, the answer is January 25th.<n><n>- The calculation: Given that the birthday of your cousin is on January 25th, and that "you can see your cousion 2 days before his bithday", "today can be" January 24th. The "can be" because of course the date changes every year, but we can always find a day around the same time every year as the birth day of our cousin.<n><n>Given that: January 25th<n>Is today: January 23rd or 24rth<n><n>Answer: D. January 23th or 24th<n><n>### Demo:<n>**Input: 1. A bird could fly with such power and speed that it could travel from England to France in one hour. 2. The French were so fascinated by the bird that they ordered the birds from England to try something similar with a message about the upcoming war between the two countries.**<n><n>- Given that a bird can fly from England to France and back to England all in one hour, can the same bird fly back and forth in an hour? The answer is yes.<n><n>- Given that the French were fascinated with the bird, they ordered the bird from England to deliver message about the war in one hour. Can that same bird travel and deliver the message in one hour? The answer is also yes.<n><n>Answer: Yes.<n><n>### Demo

Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		 C: puzzle box<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: What is made out of only what out of one piece? Choices A: 10 seconds B: 20 seconds C: 30 seconds D: 40 seconds E: 50 seconds<n>Rationales: A, C, and E all involve multiple pieces, though not identical ones, so none of them can be the correct answer. Choice B is more complicated: a 10-second is a unit of time, and could potentially be carved out of one piece. However, it is clearly ambiguous whether seconds is referring to seconds of a longer time period (5 days, 1 years, etc.), or seconds as part of a "normal" second. Similarly, choice D is ambiguous as to whether it is a reference to a unit of time (hours, minutes, seconds) or a measurement (10 seconds long). Therefore, the correct answer is C: 30 second, which refers to only 30 seconds (the shortest amount of time we can count in seconds), and clearly cannot be "carved out" of one piece.<n><n>Comment: I was told to include all the instructions and responses in case there are any changes.

Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is D: parking garages.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1. The question tells the reader that the man no longer was able to commute by driving, so he must walk instead.<n>2. When walking becomes more trouble than it is worth, where else would he be walking to and from but his home?<n>3. The only word that answers to that purpose is `home`, and it would not fit in with the rest of the sentence because it is a noun instead of a part of speech that the rest of the sentence is constructed around. Hence, the only noun that actually works at the moment of analysis is `garage`.<n>4. We can deduce the following pieces of information that do not follow the pattern of that garage is probably the parking garage.<n>    - The man does not have to commute by _garage_ anymore. <n>    - The man still has to walk to and from _garage_ after commuting.<n>5. We can now narrow down the possible choices, because we know that it cannot be a `drop-off area` or the `repair shop` (which is a noun but not an `area`). The only thing left is the `parking garage`.

Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		<n>A [chainring](/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chainring) is a component of a bicycle that allows a chain to be placed on the bike. The chainring connects the chain to the bike's front wheel, allowing the chain and the wheel to rotate in unison. To screw a chainring onto something would, thus, be to attach a chainring to a bicycle.<n><n><n>### Other input<n><n>Input: What happens when you put salt on a slug? Choices: 1. A: it dies 2. Choices:  A: arrogate B: retain C: embrace D: smile E: engage<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. The question asks us to describe the subject's action, and the clues given in it suggest that whatever we choose would also suggest a corresponding reaction on the part of the enemy they were fighting. The question thus puts a great deal of contextual weight on our answer and is therefore heavily dependent on the choices available.<n>2. "Abandon" would signal the opposite action, and suggest a correspondingly different reaction from the enemy, which would make A and D incorrect (and I consider both of them to be wrong anyway since Bill is unlikely to smile or smile to an enemy).<n>2. "Arrogate" or "Retain" have the correct tone of action and reaction but do not fit the context; they imply a taking of ownership of something, and would suggest an enemy's either surprise or grudging agreement, which does not seem reasonable given the use of "fight" and "fighting" in the question.<n>4. "Embrace" also makes more sense than some of the choices; this makes us think of holding the enemy, and the enemy being taken by surprise; however, this is a relatively weak action in the context of the wording in the question.<n>5. Finally, the remaining choices E ("Engage") and D ("Smile") are just too outlandish to be right. We can rule them out and narrow down to A and B, and for convenience reasons and in order to save some time, I'll go with A as being more reasonable.

Choices:  A: sleep in while camping B: camp ground C: woods D: bag E: backpack<n><n>### Response:		<n>As the question is written, there are 3 errors in the sentence (using a different tense, grammar and capitalization).<n>In order to have a complete answer, one must have all 3 correct. If the first two are correct, but the third is an answer choice, it would not be a complete answer.<n><n>The question is vague, as it does not direct me to a specific part of the body to place your tent.<n><n>To address the first issue, the sentence reads: "Where can you store you (or your) tent and keep it on you person?<n><n>The correct sentence should read: "Where can you put your tent and keep it on "your" person?<n><n>To address the second issue, which is grammar, use the past tense. You can place your tent in a tent (tent site) or sleep in a tent while camping. It is clear from the question that the person should place their tent in a tent/camp site.<n><n>The correct sentence would read:  "You can put your tent in "a" tent (tent site).<n><n>Addressing the third issue, capitalization: You should "keep it on your person," which is one sentence. Instead, the question is written as "Keep it on your person."<n><n>The correct sentence: "Keep it on "your" (singular) person.<n><n>Answer: A: tent site<n><n>### Instructions: How does your life resemble a road trip with the family?<n><n>### Demostration: <n>Family road trips involve many things:<n>- long trips (typically over hundreds of miles of wilderness) that requires several days of driving and stopping<n>- traveling to a new place (in this case, your new career / life)<n>- preparations before leaving, including:<n>    - packing for the travel (a.k.a. resume writing in this case)<n>    - making travel arrangements<n>    - getting food / taking care of other needs<n><n>The family members are typically notified in advanced that there's a road trip planned and all prepare in advance<n><n>Additionally, they typically have a schedule for when and for how long to stop for breaks, meals, and such so that they can stay on schedule and arrive in a reasonable amount of time.<n><n>### Response to instructions:<n>- I have not yet

Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		<n>Buildings can be described as "underground" if they are actually underground (meaning the inside of the building is in a cave, as opposed to an above-ground underground-like building like a trench, which can not be described as "under-ground").<n><n>A "high" object describes an object that is located high off the ground, such as a skyscraper. The Empire State Building is one such building.<n>There is no such thing as an "under-high building", so therefore the answer is B: "high".<n><n>### Input:`She is very intelligent and hard working, just to give you a reference point` what does `she` refer to? <n>Choices:  A: the new manager `she`s going to be replacing  B: the new intern `she`s going be responsible for  C: the company `she`s going work for<n><n>### Demostration:<n>A "new manager" is someone who has recently (or is about to) start a new role as a manager in a company, whereas a "new employee" is someone who is new to the company but without a new promotion or job responsibility.<n>Similarly for a "new intern"; new interns would have recently been hired, while an existing employee who is taking temporary responsibilities for a coworker in a different company would not likely be described as "new".<n>These descriptions therefore narrow the list of possible referents for "she" to "the company `she`s gone to work for" or "the manager `she`s about to replace".<n><n>Since "she" is referring to the new manager the correct answer is B.

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. There is a problem of a lack of food at home that means they cannot eat there. There is something they can do to the dinner situation. There is some effort that will be required. The only thing to cook at home is dinner. We know they wanted to eat at home and must make some food because we're told 'cupboards were barren' and we know there isn't any food if there is nothing to cook what is 'dinner' the subject was talking about.<n><n>### Choices<n><n>* The word 'go' (to the supermarket) is a verb - it does not describe the food in a literal way (like the way 'cook' does).<n>* The word 'back' is being used differently that we would think. 'back' means to return to a place to go back to the beginning. To return to work or to go back to the start (where they started from). They are not returning to where they started from to eat a meal, they should just cook. This means the word 'back' is not an option here.<n>* A person does not need to make food when going on a first date or the first day at a restaurant.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: He left the restaurant thinking, "Would I do this again?" and what conclusion did he come to? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The color yellow is associated with the opposite of the characteristic, what is it? Choices:  A: fearless B: english carrier C: courageous D: brave E: achromatic<n><n>### Response:		<n>Yellow can be associated with fearless(Brave),english carrier(fearlessness),courageous(free from fear) and brave(fearless but not always).<n>As it can be seen that all these traits are diametrically opposite of each other this will be one of the ways of interpreting the question.<n>But taking "courageous" out of it, this can also be seen like a test.<n>If we can associate fearlessness with bravery,can we associate bravery with courageous?<n>From my opinion, the correct answer will have to be the last one from the list and that is<n>B: english carrier(fairlessness).<n>The answer is very very similar to that of the previous question.<n><n>Answer: B: english carrie<n><n>### Inputs: The first letter of a particular number represents an animal, which? Choices:  (1) A: dog (2)B: cow (3)C: horse (4)D: sheep (5)E: chicken<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1)The phrase "first letter of a particular number represent an animal" provides significant clue that this question has nothing to do with number sequence.<n>2) the question asks for a type of animal, so the choices that are animal are to be given preference over the choices that are birds.<n><n>From this perspective taking into consideration point (1), we can eliminate ( 4).<n><n>As point (2) narrows it down to choices only (3)horse(4)dog<n>we can even eliminate (4) as the question asked for first letter of the number to represent an animal and (1) has 1st (dog),3rd(horse),4th(cow) and 5th(sheep) letter starting with dog,horse,cow and sheep<n>Thus the answer will be<n><n>B: Horse.<n><n>### Input : In the 2016 U.S. presidential election, which party received more votes? Choices: A: Republican B: Democratic C: Green Party D: Libertarian E: Communist<n><n>### Racionales:<n>To give preference we will be taking (4) and (5).<n><n>As (4) Libertarian is a party(a choice), it is possible.<n>As (5) Commun

Choices:  A: flower garden B: garden center C: pot D: pot E: formal garden<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Dear Aunt Sara,<n><n>Thank you very much for the lovely rosebush you sent me! I cannot wait to get it planted, but unfortunately I don't have any containers big enough to keep it in. I will be visiting the library soon where I will be able to borrow some of their gardening containers if you would like it that way. I would appreciate it if you could call the library and let them know how long the planters will need to be there and what size planters would work best for the rosebush. I don't care how long they need to stay there, so just let me know when the library will be able to drop them off so that I can be ready to pick them up. I hope these arrangements will work out well because I really want to get started planting the rosebush in my garden. Have a great day!<n><n>Your niece,<n>Lisa<n><n>### Input What do you call a t-rex who can't write his own name?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A writer-expressed, non-extinction tyrannosaurus.<n>

There can also be slippery conditions caused by rain that could result in injuries.<n><n>### Input2:The what are located at places called terminals? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: engineering school C: san francisco D: tree E: market<n><n>### Response:		<n>I like this question! What's funny about it is that it's ambiguous. There are many possibilities when it asks if you can eat fruit on a red _bridge_. For one thing, maybe you're hungry and want to know where you can satisfy your hunger instead of where you can eat food. The question doesn't specify that the bridge isn't in a hospital, so maybe you can ask in the doctor's office if there's any fruit there. The more I think about it, the more possibilities there are. It is so vauge that most people would have difficulty solving it.<n>### Demonstartion:What is your favorite fruit? "C" does not stand for Cacao, so It is not Cacao.<n>5. The sentence "it should be obvious that we eat all of our fruit inside the red box" suggests apricot.<n><n>### How the hell did you go through a whole fruit-list?<n><n>

Choices:  A: utah B: south america C: new hampshire D: japan E: new mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question is asking for the answer to the hypothetical question “if I wanted to see a [l]i[z]ard in its natural habitat.” Because the word “wanted” implies that the reader is in control of the situation, the answer must begin with a pronoun or verb representing someone other than the reader, or in other words: the plural pronoun _they_. In other words, it would be grammatically incorrect to say “If I wanted XYZ.”<n><n>### What does D mean?<n><n>- D is the letter code in which position? The first, the second, the third, or the fourth position (one, two, three, or four)?<n><n>### Which of the following is the best definition of "the" as a determiner that replaces a noun?<n>A pronoun, an article, a verb, a preposition, any of the preceding,<n>- In grammar, a determiner is a function word that modifies the meaning of a noun. The definite article _the_ is a determiner.<n>- The words _a, some,_ _many_ are called _indefinite articles_ because they do not refer to a particular, specific person, place or thing. <n>- _A_ is an indefinite noun meaning "one" or "a single one of an unspecified number." In grammar, article(noun) a or an is an indefinite article used before a singular noun that does not refer to a specific, particular person or thing in the universe, but only to a person or thing without specifying which one.<n><n>### Which part of speech is the following word in the sentence?<n>I don't like her<n>- In English grammar, a word (part of speech) is a unit of language (a single letter, sound, word, or phrase) with its own particular meaning. Words are the building blocks of language.<n>- Words are divided into (two parts: ) two parts: open class and closed class, which can each be subdivided into more specific types.<n>- There are many words in the world, but they are not all made equal. Grammatically speaking, not all words are made equal, either. <n><n>### In the sentence, "My friend is very good at playing the piano," what is the part of speech of the word "friend"?<n>A noun,

But then I can't remember if I ate the sandwich or soup for dinner last night or not"<n><n>### Input, "I haven't bought a bagel yet today. Which is odd, since I would usually have one before 9AM."<n><n>### Response, "I had bought one bagel yesterday, and planned to buy another today. I wonder why I bought one yesterday then?"<n><n>### Input "What are you looking at now?"<n><n>### Instution:Write a response with context that describes what you are looking at.<n><n>### Rationale:The context of the prompt indicates that the response should describe the subject as being currently engaged in a visual activity and include specific descriptions. It does not provide any indication that the subject should be asked a question or give any information related to their thoughts. I think I should go."<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that accurately and clearly defines the word or expression. Explain how you know what the word or expression means in this particular case.<n><n>### Input"It wasn't easy, but I managed to get the job done before the deadline despite all of the what was put before me."<n><n>### Rationales:1. What is it:<n>    - the context implies that the "it" refers to something done by the subject. Since the whole sentence implies that something was done with success, it could be a task, assignment, plan, etc.<n>    - in line 1, it is implied that "the subject" is referring to the subject.<n>    - the subject claims to be successful in the completion of the task, which makes sense if it is something they are working on.<n>2

This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:After new coke was discontinued what formula was used? Choices:  A: original B: old C: coke clear D: former E: familiar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The formula was used for Coke clear.<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>1. "After Coca-Cola was discontinued" implies that "Coke Clear" also was discontinued. This suggests that Coke Clear is also Coke. Coke Clear was an attempt by Coke to re-introduce a clear cola to compete with Pepsi Clear and was discontinued in 2004 due to not enough sales.<n>2. The question is asking for what formula was Coke Clear based off and not what formula is Coke based off of.<n>3. The other choices are incorrect. "Coke Clear" is no longer being sold.<n><n>### Tips:<n><n>In some questions, you may need to identify what is being asked. <n><n>> Note: This is not a typical pattern testing problem given by Google. It is a typical one used by test prep tutors for their workshop training. <n><n>### Answer:

We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What does reckless driving lead to on a person? Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		 Reckless driving leads to numerous and diverse possible outcomes, depending on how extreme the driving is. "Reckless driving," as the question states, is defined as "driving in a manner that indicates a conscious and willful disregard for the safety of persons or property."<n><n>The possible outcomes of reckless driving can be roughly broken down into two groups: 1. Those that cause tangible harm to the individual driving or others and 2. Those that cause harm only to the driver or create minor inconveniences.<n><n>Tangible outcomes can include injuries or fatalities, either to the driver themselves such as in a car crash, or as a third party affected by the reckless driving, such as by falling debris while driving down rain-soaked pavement. Traffic jams and other accidents that result from reckless driving, however, are not direct causes for injuries or fatalities; these are more likely the result of reckless driving, not a direct cause.<n><n>"Tire treads can cause accidents by losing some of their tread depth," according to [What You Need to Know About Tires and Tread Depth](https://cars.usnews.com/cars-trucks/tips/what-you-need-to-know-about-tires-and-tread-depth). Tire treads are directly involved in driving and are impacted by improper or reckless driving, so this is classified as a tangible outcome.<n><n>The phrase, "tired E: accidents" also gives some potential outcomes. <n><n>"Being tired while driving increases the risk of an accident," according to [The Effects of Being Tired While Driving](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/05/08/the-effects-of-being-tired_n_559726.html). This also provides a tangible result, but its indirect nature means it is not as likely as a direct result. There is no clear relationship between "tired" and "accidents;" the association of each one can be made based on being an abstract concept. So, this cannot be the true outcome.<n>    - "Reckless driving [...] leads to fatigue and can [be] indirectly related to accidents
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct choice for the "Input question" would be A. In the "Input" portion of the question we are referring to an attempt to confirm applicant's reference that would fail if the reference did what? This question is asking what would cause an applicant's potential employer to fail to get in contact with their previous employer. The other choices suggest different ways that an employer might actually contact a previous employer, so they are incorrect.<n>There are two main things which an employer can contact their previous employer about for a previous employee they interviewed who would fail them to get in contact.<n><n>**The first choice**<n>> An employee's job can be terminated for a variety of reasons, including poor performance. In this case, the employer refuses to give employment reference to a sub-par employee as he believes that his company would not like him to vouch for that employee again in the future.<n><n>**The second choice**<n>> The other reason can be if the previous employer had found out that the new job applicant doesn't disclose his whole working experience during a job interview. He was, say, fired for misbehavior and the new company is inquiring about the details of the employee's termination with the previous company. The last thing they (previous employer) wants to do is damage their reputation with future employers by being blasted as untrustworthy with their former employees.<n><n>### Answer: A: question<n><n>### Input<n>Input in this kind of test usually means, "what should you answer for the following questions? " So, for this question we are given the following questions, to answer.<n>### Demontration and Rationale:<n>In the instruction it says, "Write a response that appropriately complete(s) the request", and for that "request" it is the following questions...<n><n>* What time class begins<n>* The reason for the student's absence for the past week<n>* The best place to sit and study<n>* The teacher's favorite subject to teach<n>* To leave an exam in the box on the desk<n>* What the student's hobbies are besides basketball<n><n>So, we would look at the possible answers in each choice and see which choice would be relevant.<n><n>### Choice A: Student's hobbies outside of basketball <n><n>### Choices

Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:John is getting something important.  What does this make him feel? Choices:  A: then have B: headaches C: stoic D: being happy E: wanting more<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>John is getting something important, what does this make him feel. This answer can be A: then have B : headaches C: stoical D: being happy E : wanting more. the answer is C: stoical.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>In which "then" "headaches"  "stoical" "being happy" and "wanting more" are the answers. The first step in problem analysis is to carefully read the entire problem, not just the question. The first line of the problem tells us that John is getting something important. We can use the process of elimination to determine that the answer cannot be A: Headaches, because headaches do not suggest anything to do with obtaining or receiving something. This is an easy case of elimination -- looking at the options and ruling out things that don't make sense.<n><n>Secondly, the phrase "stoic is a very strong clue for choosing the answer. A stoic is a person who does not allow their mood or attitude to be easily influenced by things happening around them. When thinking about John getting something important, a reasonable question to think about is what will he be feeling, based on the fact that he is getting something important.<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question. <n><n>###Explanation:<n>I am a high school student and I love my friends and I like my teachers and I love playing soccer and I dream about travelling. The answer is A: high school<n><n>###Exaplanation:[Ascend](http://www.ascend.academon.com/lessons/details.php?lid=2454)<n><n><n>###Instructions: Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>###Demonstation:[Ascend](https://www.ascendedu.com/lessons-pdf/8430/index.pdf)<n><n>###Input:What are we all thinking about right?<n><n>###Answer: C: the future<n><n>###The future:The future can hold unlimited possibilities, from simple ambitions of getting a new job to complex visions of a utopic society. The phrase "we all are thinking about right" makes clear that we are not thinking about something in the present, but rather about what will be in the future. <n><n>##

The correct answer is "B: movies".<n><n>### Source: The "silver screen", meaning a large film display, dates back to the early 1900s. It was named for the silver nitrate that was sometimes used as a film chemical, but was so corrosive that the nitrate could be flammable at the time. (2021, April, 13) How to use "silver screen" in a sentence | HowToPronounce.com. Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		In a competitive sport, such as basketball, spectators are interested in seeing one winner.<n><n>### Rationales: 1) The teams were evenly matched. Which tells us that they are evenly competitive, which in this situation is good for fans. Fans want to see the best match up.<n>2) In terms of what we are asking, the question asks "what spectators wanted." There isn't a definite answer, however, most of the time the result of a basketball game is that there is one winner.<n>3) Most spectators want to see one team be defeated, so by being evenly matched, we are increasing the chances of one team being defeated over the other. Thus, we will see one winner.<n><n>Rationale 3 is incorrect. Spectators are not necessarily interested in who wins, as a number of fans may dislike either team, but rather the quality of the teams. A match where the better team wins is more satisfying for fans compared to a match where the underdog team won, even if it was by one point.<n>Spectators of any sport are interested in watching a team win.<n><n>### Task<n>Input:In the beginning of the new contract, the player would get to earn $190,000 per year. As such, your responses should be a summary of that response, but written in paragraph form. <n>2. **Annotate**: Annotated explanations use the writing rubrics (see below) to identify strengths and weaknesses of the response. You must write one to three sentences per prompt analyzing where you were successful and where you were not. Note that annotating responses is mandatory in all courses, but you may not need to explain every sentence--just the key ones.<n>3. **Cite Sources**: All writing responses must show evidence of having read at least three sources on a topic, but students may be required to give more or fewer cited sources according to the writing genre. Sources may be found in books, newspapers, magazines, etc. If you do not know how to do citations, see the links below. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The crab was scuttling but strained when he moved, what was impeding him? Choices:  A: tide pool B: beach sand C: tidepools D: current E: cooking pot<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A: tide pool<n><n>

Choices:  A: the roof B: storage cabinet C: car trunk D: retail store E: home<n><n>### Response:		<n>What's another good place to store a shopping bag in your car. I'm looking for more flexible and cheaper options than having to shop at home.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The choice of response is correct. The speaker's answer (the roof) is a good one to have prepared in case the interviewer wants to confirm that you have thought about it.<n><n>The choice of rationale is correct as it reassures me that you have thought this through; however, it also suggests that you may be looking for other options or that you do not want to be responsible for the items while in your car. If you pick option B (storage cabinet) be very clear that you will hold these items throughout the ride.<n><n>### Input How are we different than a retail chain in Australia, Canada, and Europe? We don't use the word "franchising." The correct answer is B and we were not trying to be funny. When trying to think quickly or if you are unsure of the answer write down the question first. Then write down any ideas that come to mind. You should always make an answer when the question is asked. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The helm is not something you wear on your head. Rather, it moves the masts on what? Choices:  A: sailing vessel B: paddleboat C: ship D: motorboat E: tugboat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**My Response**: <n><n>*The helm is not worn on your head.<sup>[1]</sup> Rather, it moves masts on a **ship.**<sup>[2]**"<n>  My answer has the logical conclusion, that the phrase `The helm is not...` is a negative phrase and implies that what follows should be a thing (an entity) you can wear for helm to move the masts of what. So, the conclusion that `is not` applies to something (an entity) and following that is a `what` that can be a headgear (a hat). Because it does not apply to the `head` it would not apply to a human's head, and so on the helm, an object, does not wear on a head.<n><n>  The rest of the sentence, "Rather, it moves the Masts on... **ship**" is logically and contextually applicable to the question of what can the helm move the masts on. Therefore, the answer must be Ship <sup>[3]**".<n><n>  *The helm is not an article of wear, rather a helm is something on a ship that moves the masts on a ship.<n><n>### Input:"I've had it with you and your constant complaining, and I don't want to hear about it <sup>[4]**"<n><n>### Response<n>"I don't want to have something I've had it with, the constant complaining. And I don't want complain about it anymore, it's something you never want to have heard about"<n><n>Notice in the response that we took the conclusion from the "You" and "Complaining" and "Complaint" and "Had" which are in the same sentence and "Constant Complaining". "You and your" is the thing referred to by the subject. "And I" is the part of the message that the first had and the second had, "It" is referring to the complaining which the subject does not want to hear about anymore.<n><n>### The response to the first question has the sentence:<n>>Answer: B: promotion  <n>>My Response:  "The helm is not a headgear, rather the helm is an object you wear on the ship that moves the mast on a ship

This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What area is likely to contain a large village? Choices:  A: rural area B: big city C: suburbs D: ohio E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: A person is likely to find a large village in what area? Choices: A: rural area B rural area C: suburbs answer: D rural area<n><n>### Explanation: <n><n>### Hint:<n><n>#### Rural Areas<n>are areas not usually associated with a city or town. For example, rural areas have a rural lifestyle and are filled with different kinds of homes - houses, trailers, and cabins - and there are usually a lot of animals roaming around. Additionally, you will find more dirt roads in the rural areas.<n><n>### Hints for the following questions:<n>1. 5 people are riding in a car and there are two dogs in the back. If I go in the front, then two people sit in the back. If no one goes in the back, two people go in the front. How many people can ride in this car?<n>2. Find out what all of the following animals (and their sounds) have in common: pig - oink, cow - moo, duck - quack, tiger - roar, cat - meow, turtle - hum?<n>3. There are 5 cups, each with a different colored liquid in them. The colors are brown, blue, red, yellow and green. How many different pairs of matching colors do you see?<n>#### Answer:<n>1. If 2 people go in the back, that leaves 3 seats in the front. But 1 person is riding with the pig in the front and 5 people in the back means that 3 people would be left riding. That means 6 people can ride in the car.<n>2. The answers are pig - oink and duck - quack.<n>3. Two. The only combinations that would work are brown and blue and green and yellow. The other pair can't work, as one would be brown, with a red cup and a yellow cup. This would not make sense as there'd be a red cup with an orange cup, or a blue cup with a green cup.

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demolition: The words "kids" and "apartment" convey a college setting, while also suggesting that there are no fully functional living facilities available. This might come from lack of housing options, or it could be that the people living there have recently moved out of a bigger space, and have no fully functional furniture to fill it with.<n><n>The given phrase "folding chair inside their room" suggests that the living space they're occupying is small, that they must be using furniture that cannot be permanently fitted into their room, which further implies that this might not be a fully functional room. This can most likely be resolved only by moving out and getting one's own place, which we know from the context that college students do not have the money for.<n><n>As a whole, the given hints suggest that people (most likely college students) are currently stuck residing in a home that cannot be decorated and furnished, and must be satisfied with subpar living conditions due to financial constraints. The only word that fits this description is E: church, as churches usually do not have proper homes for congregants to stay in.<n><n>Answer: E: church.<n><n>### Input (cont.): They were known for their incessant what? Choices: A: chainsmoking B: vandalism C: drinking D: chattering E: complaining F: racket<n><n>### Responses:<n><n>Demolition 1: The given words "inexorable smoking" suggests a habit incessantly performed during certain durations of time. As one might associate smoking with either pleasure or stress, and the given context that these people are most likely college students, we can infer that it is the act of smoking that is going on as long as the speaker is present. Therefore, since "chattering" involves having a very long and incessant conversation, it would not fit. There is no hint given that speakers might have the tendency of excessive talking, so this alternative is out. Complaining could apply to complaining about anything, which means it is still too vague an answer. Similarly, while vandalism or drinking in itself could be incessant, as in continuously practiced, the given phrase "what they were known for" implies that they are known for their incessent drinking or their incessent vandal

Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		The answer to this question is "A: bathe." The word "study" in the sentence indicates that John is interested in learning about animals and observing their behavior.  "John is studying animals" <n>What is one of the many ways John can observe and learn about animals' physical behaviors is to watch them bathe.<n>Answer: A:bathe<n><n>### Input : The man who just finished his exam is happy that he ___ and that he got a high score. Choices:  A.got away with something B. got home safely C. aced the test D. had a great time E. passed the exam<n><n>### Demostration : 1. The phrase "The man who just finished his exams" in the question indicates that the subject in the question has just recently completed an exam. An exam is often taken for an evaluation of academic knowledge and to achieve a particular grade or result.<n>2. In the sentence that follows, "his" refers to the subject from the sentence above, and it's important to pay attention to the pronouns (the subject of the verb) in context in order to be able to correctly answer the question. We can see that the phrases "got away with something", "had a great time", and "passed the exam" all refer to things that the subject did.<n>3. The subject then talks about what they did- how they got home, how well they passed their exam, or how happy they are that passed their exam, but what they did (studying in this case) is what is most important to the sentence, and the phrases above refer to actions, behaviors, or events, as opposed to feeling. Therefore, the most likely answer would be E.<n>Answer: E: "that he passed the exam"<n><n>### Input A: I have just read that  many of us have a certain percentage of our brains that we never use, and can be damaged. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Lizards need the sun's heat to regulate their body temperature, this is why you'll see them still on what? We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where should you find a school in? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: mosque C: every city D: prague E: community<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Notice that the problem uses a passive verb, "should" be located in a specific area. The question refers to a location that is in the plural, so it has two possible interpretations: "where should you find two schools" and " where should you find a school." If it meant "where should you locate one school," it would be singular and only would have one answer. Since it is plural, it must be referring to two possible locations of multiple schools. The answer, then, is "two cities" since cities, not neighborhoods, can contain several schools in one area.

Given that, the sentence may conclude that the letter has some unique feature that attracts the reader’s attention or that the author wants to read the letter for some important reason because the conclusion says “might read” which implies that the answer may contain a feature which prompts the reader to read it.<n><n>### Rationale 1:<n>The rationale starts with “pudding”. The word “pudding” stands for a sweet food. In addition, the passage contains the word “news” which stands for information related to what is happening in a particular place. Given that, the reader might receive the letter from overseas (e.g. foreign travelers or people returning to their homeland) and that this letter could be used as news if the reader is interested in something happening in the writer’s country.<n><n>### Choice (A): pudding. It turns out, given the information presented in the question and by analyzing the word “pudding”, that the writer has returned from overseas and wants to inform the reader of some news.<n>### Rationale2:<n>After writing “pudding”, the passage then mentions some interesting features by mentioning “strain”. This can be interpreted as the writer has gone through some difficult times in his/her foreign traveling due to a difficult or strange country (e.g. war, poverty, etc.) or because of personal struggles like marriage, childbirth, death of family members, etc. Hence, the letter may include some interesting information related to the subject’s difficulties and may make the reader read it more.<n><n>### Answer: Choice (B): because of personal struggles<n><n>### Input:[If](https://opentext.ubc.ca/chapter/writing-an-informative-essay/reading-comprehension-and-multiple- choice-items/) you could take a walk in the park before work, would you do so? Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: There are many things you could be doing while traveling. Choices:  A. sleeping B. getting a new radio C. doing homework D. reading E. practicing<n>Rationales:1. Given that the subject is doing "many things," it is safe to assume that we are on a car ride, perhaps even a long one and that they aren't sleeping. Thus, the only true logical answer would be doing homework. This also fits best as the wording "getting a new radio" is ambiguous. It could mean getting a new car radio, which is something you could be doing while in a car. However, this phrase also suggests the car itself is being replaced, which doesn't make logical sense. Likewise, the phrase "reading" sounds like it would be a hassle while driving, especially when considering its placement in the option set.<n>Answer: D. reading homework<n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Some stores trick women to buy products, the sales make it seem like if you buy more you what? Choices:  A: get money B: pay money C: go shopping D: lose money E: save money<n><n>### Response:		<n>D) lose money <n><n>### Inputs:<n>1. "Some stores trick women to by products." 2. The sales make it seem like, if you buy more you. 3. Get money 4. Pay money 5. Go shopping <n> <n>### Redection:<n>1. If you buy more you get money. 2. But if you lose money then they get money.

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What part of the body are lips on? Choices:  A: mouth B: jars and all faces C: kentucky fried chicken D: hand E: human<n><n>### Response:		<n>The mouth is a cavity in any animal's jaw where it is able to ingest, chew, and swallow food and water, and these are all features that are not associated with lips in any animals or humans. This rules out choices A, B, and C.<n><n>Now we should see if any features on the human body is shared by choice E. This is not the case. This eliminates choice E as well.<n><n>Finally, we should analyze the word "on" in the stimulus. The word "on" is a part of speech called an adverb of position.<n><n>Adverbs of position tell us where an animal is. A human's mouth is on the human face, not anywhere else. Therefore, since choice D is the only correct answer, the correct answer is D: hand.<n><n>Answer: D: hand<n>

Choices:  A: office building B: schoolroom C: library D: bedroom E: gym<n><n>### Response:		<n>The input is ambiguous and contains two separate sentences. It is not clear whether, for instance, "where would you find a des...?" is asking about finding a desk, or about the desk itself being a young person, who then could occupy the seat at a desk. Given such ambiguity, the response would be to say that the desk is normally occupied by a young adult and therefore does not fall into the choices of A-E.<n><n>Answer: B: schoolroom<n><n>### Input:(An)other student in this class is a teacher.<n><n>### Response:(An)other student is a teacher.<n>The input contains three distinct, but grammatically connected, elements: "(an)another student in this class is" is the primary clause. It is followed by a pronoun, "is a teacher," and ends with a full statement: "(an)other student in this"<n><n>### Input<n>(An)other student in that class is a teacher. This sentence has two main clauses, the first of which is a complement to "(an)other student," as the whole of the sentence is a complement to "[An]other student in that class."<n><n>### Input(s): <n>Some of the students in this or that class (would) like to become actors.<n>The phrase "...and so forth" indicates that the students are a sampling of the whole group. The phrases "(would) like to" and (could) (would) indicate intent and hypotheticals. The clause contains the antecedent for "some." It should be (s).<n><n>### Input (s): <n>If [some] of the students in that class is not a teacher, then they are not as good as that student in (an)other class.<n>The sentence begins with "(some) of the students in that...," which is a predicate nominative. The predicate nominative "is" does not match up with the verb, "is not" and the phrase "that student..." lacks an object complement to the verb. In addition, the phrase "in that class" is the object complement of "a(n)other class."<n><n>## Input:<n>* If [one] of your classmates (or) your co-workers is a teacher, then we can (should) give them some support and advice.<n>The sentence begins "(or) your

This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What could someone be doing while performing that cannot be enjoyed by deaf people? Choices:  A: smile B: singing C: sweat D: act E: dance<n><n>### Response:		<n>"What could someone be doing that cannot be enjoyed by [someone who is] deaf people?" Here we are given the context that something "cannot be enjoyed," which narrows down the possible answers. The question also follows the formula A: ___ B: ___. These clues tell us that A, the first part of the sentence, describes a group of people, while B, the second part if the sentence, describes a type of activity. Based on this information, we can quickly cross off "act" and "dance" as choices: an act refers to behavior or speech and is not something one could not do, since everyone can act, while the same goes for dancing. This makes the remaining answers A: smoke, B: talk, or C: drink.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### 5. Demonstration: Input: I was having lunch with my parents and brother when I felt I had a good understanding of the difference between what our family believes and wants. Choices:<n>A: the need for a relationship B: the need within a relationship C: the belief that love is important D: the need for understanding E: the need for commitment<n><n><n>### Rationales: 1 Our first clue is the word “when.” Most authors start their paragraphs with an introductory clause (also known as a statement or sentence) and use transition signals (words or phrases that help the reader understand the relationship between a sentence and the rest of the paragraph). This helps keep readers from being too surprised or shocked when they read certain content. An introductory clause helps the reader know what to expect. In this case, the idea of lunch is a type of a transition idea. This allows us to know that we will be given more information.<n><n>2. We are given more information regarding the lunch, and the word “believe” in this sentence gives us a clue that is going to be talking about some religion or beliefs. “believe” is used to refer to things that you believe because you want more information about. <n><n>3. Paragraphs begin with an introductory statement that describes a situation or what is going on with the author in some way. These introductory sentences should not be confused with topic sentences (the sentences that start paragraph

The phrase "with ink" implies the possibility of filling something else with ink.<n>2. The word "print," in this context, should refer to printing paper, rather than printing images. This would make sense; it is unlikely that one would refer to printing as "squid-ing" or "pencil-ing."<n><n>Hence, the most logical answer is D, fountain pen.

How did they make their final presentation memorable? There was something about that idea that seemed to stand out, but what was different about it? What could the team now do with that fresh set of A, B, C, D, or E?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: D:<n>A, B, C, and E are four-letter words followed by a letter from the English alphabet from A to E. It is obvious that we just need to combine the four-letter words. For example,<n><n>1 C = The project became a big hit.<n>2 D = The project became a complete hit.<n><n>So, the complete answer would be "The project became a complete hit."

Choices:  A: loss of consciousness B: relaxation C: snoring D: dreaming E: talking<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### The correct answer is<n><n>A) loss of consciousness<n><n>#### My justification is<n><n>The question gives us two main clues to help us narrow down our possible answers:<n><n>1) "...when going to sleep." This implies the subject is falling asleep. <n><n>2) "...the sound made by a human." <n><n>However, there are also some additional subtle clues.<n><n>At first glance this might suggest A or B, but then in closer analysis, it becomes apparent that A is too specific and B can more clearly be narrowed down to a narcoleptic or the hypothetical case of a patient undergoing a medically assisted coma. Choices: A: My (husband) and I are about one week away from becoming empty nest emotionally.<n>B: My and I are about one year away from becoming empty nest financially.<n>C: My and I are one month away from becoming independent financial-wise but emotionally a long way off. D: My and I are two years away from becoming empty nest physically.<n>E: My and I are almost two years away from an empty nest financially. Answer:<n>A: My (husband's) and I are one month <n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: An "empty nest" is an apartment without one's children.<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. The phrase "empty nest" is commonly used as a metaphor for children leaving home.<n>2. The word "month" in the sentence indicates that they have had time to prepare for this transition. The phrase" my husband and I are about" indicates the both parties are making a joint decision.<n><n>3. Looking at all these, the most logical answer choice is B: "My and I are one year away from an empty nest." There is no way for a married couple to have become empty nesters without preparing for it for at least one year. Choice C would be incorrect choice, no metaphorically way in which children can leave the nest within two months.<n><n>### Answer:<n>B. Choices:  A. In a chair B. Under a tree C. With friends D. In the cafeteria E: At school<n><n>### Instructions: Write as much as you wish to describe a situation. If you finish early, skip ahead and write the same amount again. Then, answer the questions.<n><n>### It is Saturday afternoon, a week before Christmas. I should be at home in Virginia taking a break from my job in Washington, but instead I am sitting here in the dark in this empty theater, having just finished a 12-hour shift as a projectionist.<n><n>### Projectionists are the least popular people in a movie theater. People feel sorry for us all the time because of our long hours and low wages; they assume there’s nothing but tedium and boredom for us to do in this job. But believe me, working with all those movies and constantly watching screens and talking to moviegoers at my podium is by far more interesting than sitting here in the dark. The only person I’ll get to talk to soon is the young black guy in the doorway with the cigar in a hand and the other hand in his pocket, looking for the entrance to the bathroom in the back of the lobby.<n>All the other seats are empty.<n>I don’t often get a chance to sit down between shifts, and as I wait for the next film I decide to read some of the newspaper clippings on the posters I had put up in the lobby last year.<n>I see my name on a picture of an abandoned theater in New York City. “The man who was arrested today for the murder of his wife and himself has a checkered past, having once worked at a theater in the city of Washington under the name of Willie. Some colleagues described his manner as odd, claiming he had a deep-seated fear of movie projectionists.”<n>I look farther down the article and see a photo of the theater where I work.
