For what group of people could one use this meaning? Choices:  C: those who are always talking about money D: people who spend their money E: people who don't get paid enough<n>A. The correct answer is B. people who try to make more money.  <n><n>### Demystify:<n><n>#### 1. What is the best way to find out exactly what a writer was thinking when they wrote the prompt?<n><n>*  Find the author's intention (a) and their thesis (b), then determine how you as a reader might connect them.<n>*  Determine whether the clues are straightforward or subtle.<n>*  Read the prompt more than once if necessary, being sure to closely read the first, second, and last sentence.<n><n>*  Be aware of the author's use of sarcasm or irony, as these devices can change the meaning of the sentence.<n><n>* When the questions ask what the writer intended, remember the writer's meaning doesn't always coincide with the reader's. Questions often ask what the writer means and this is an indicator of confusion about the prompt.  <n><n>#### 2. What does the author want you to understand about this sample prompt?<n><n>The author wants the reader to understand how a person being sarcastic is referring to another person being greedy and money-oriented.  <n>* Be aware of the author’s use of sarcasim or irony, as device may change the meaning.  <n>* Be familiar with the structure of an IR questions.  <n>* Read the the first, second and last sentence closely.  <n>* Find author's intention and their thesis.  <n>* Read more than once if necessary<n><n>#### 3. What are some strategies for identifying the author’s purpose?<n>A. The author is always clear in what he/she is trying to convey, <n>* Find the author's thesis, <n>* Find author'ss intention, <n>* Be careful with understanding of sarcasm and irony, <n>* Read the first, second and forth sentences closely, <n>* Read more than one time if necessary<n><n>##### a.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If I have a vintage, decorative light source in my possession, what is it likely to be? Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E: lamp<n><n>#### Rationales<n>1. It is highly likely that if you have a vintage decorative light source in your possession, it is a lamp as lighting is very highly relevant to a decorative setting. While other light sources such as the sky are also decorative in nature, candle, house and sun are not as commonly used for decorative use. Lamps, on the other hand, are a great addition to the decorative atmosphere of any room.<n>2. The problem description states that the subject has a vintage decoration light source in their possession, implying that it has a retro feel or old vintage vibe. Lamp can be used in many situations to create a unique, warm and welcoming atmosphere.<n>3. These two reasons, combined together, lead to the correct answer of E: lamp.<n><n># [Chapter 3: Tip Sheet](#chapter-3-tip-sheet)<n><n>## [Chapter 3, Quiz 3: Answer Key](#chapter-3-quiz-3-answer-key)<n><n>Chapter 3 Quiz 3, Answer Key<n><n>![Screenshot](../../../docs/assets/images/chapters/3/answerkey_quiz3.png)<n><n>### Solution:<n># [Chapter4: Tip Sheet Quiz.](#chapter4-tip-sheet-quiz)<n><n>#### ## Quiz 1.<n>You’d want to go to the place depicted in the photograph. What is it?<n><n>###### Answer: A. The Louvre.<n><n>#### [Chapter4: Quiz 2.](#chapter4-quiz-2)<n><n><n>### If you take a photo of a famous Parisian street, the one depicted in the photo could be the avenue of what?<n>#### [Quiz 1.](#chapter4-first-quiz)<n>Answers: _B_  | _E_  | _F_  | _D_  | _G_<n><n>Avenue of the Champs Élysées, Paris, France<n><n>A baker in a street bakery is making pastries in this photograph. Where in a bakery would you most likely to see her?<n><n>Answers: A bread oven | B dough production

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:A gentleman is very wealthy and flaunts it, where does he likely live? Choices:  A: europe B: big house C: tuxedo D: palace E: men's room<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the following question, what would be included in the subject's tuxedo wardrobe? Choices: 1. Pink and green socks, with the green pair underneath the pink socks. 2. An English breakfast tea set with matching cup and saucer and tea pot. 3. A matching waistcoat and cufflinks to the suit and trousers. 4. A suit, shirt and shoes.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>1. The word 'wardrobe' refers to the collection of articles of clothing one wears. Therefore, the subject's treadrobe would have to involve the entirety of their clothes including both outerwear (the jackets and suits) and underwear (the shirts and pants).<n><n>2. According to the answer choices, one of the subject's turedo would likely include a tea pot and saucer, a tea set, both the pants and the jacket, and accessories like cufflinks.<n>The only logical answer is therefore E.<n><n>### Input (Sentiment):<n><n>Taxes on the rich are a good idea, but are not likely to pass Congress which has a majority conservative party members. Which is the most likely reason that a tax hike is unlikely? Choices:  T: too much of a windfall to ignore.  B: too much of a blow to the economy.  C: too much of a tax cut for the rich.  D: too much of an issue to resolve.  E: too much of a financial hole to dig out of.<n><n>### Response (Paraphrase):<n><n>According to the instructions, the tax hike probably isn't going to happen because...? Choices: 1) Congress has a majority in conservative party members so they have a built in obstacle to any proposed tax hike. 2) Congress has a majority of conservative party members so politicians are unlikely to take on the fight of a new tax hike. 3) Congress has a majority conservative parties members and they have a big enough of a windfall to keep increasing income taxes on the rich. 4) Because the conservative parties have a majority in Congress, there is too much of an issue for them to resolve. 5) There are too many issues

The answer to finding the answer is finding the one that does not have curiosity but wants to ensure viewing enjoyments. After analyzing the choices the answer is 'Examine the thing' (B)<n><n>###  The question starts off with the word "If you are not experiencing curiosity and want ensure viewing enjoyments", by which we know that the first sentence introduces the answer, and the other five sentences introduce different choices.<n><n>###  Also based on what we know so far, because curiosity is something negative, the opposite of curiosity is the positive thing that the sentence is looking for, which is "ensure viewing enjoyment".<n><n>### Also based on the definition of curiosity: [Curiosity definition](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/english/curiosity), and the sentence "want to ensure viewing enjoyability", we can infer that the sentence means, want to view something.<n><n>That is why we should find the answer that wants to view something.<n>

Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:James lived in the top of a tall tower.  He could see clouds when he looked out his window.  Where might he live? Choices:  A: in books B: radio station C: city D: tower E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n>What is this question asking?<n>(1) Where is James?<n>(2) Does James look out his window to see clouds?<n>(3) Where does James live?<n>This is a reading comprehension question.<n><n>There's too much stuff here for me to have to go over each bit, I don't know where it all came from.<n><n>First off, I will only respond to the three questions I understand.<n><n>Question 1. Where is James?<n><n>We don't know where James is. The sentence only tells us he lives in a tower and can observe cloud from his window.<n><n>Question 2. Does James live in a cloud? I think not.<n><n>Again this question is unclear what is meant by "looks out". We don't know if he looks out of a window out of a cloud. Or if "look out" means he's just observing cloud from his window, and that he is living in a tower. If we go by logic, the sentence reads "He could see clouds," as a passive sentence. So it should be "He could have been (the part not written) in a cloud" or it's a mistake if the question is "where is he observing cloud from".<n><n>Question 3. Does he live in the tower?<n><n>It doesn't says how tall the tower is or what James wants to make of it. If I live somewhere, I can't see clouds at every angle I move around the building.<n><n>So, I don't want to guess.<n><n>I have no idea what the question is looking for.<n><n>\strong{Correction}<n>I think the question is looking for "Does James lives in the Tower or not". I didn't understand the sentence. I am assuming it looks like this "James lives in Tower, he can see clouds from his window" because of the comma.<n><n>The problem seems to be the sentence was misplaced to a wrong question. I think it should be first "Whether James lives in Cloud". if yes then second question is "Can clouds be inside a Tower." and The third is "Which tower can James live if he lives in Cloud"

Choices: 1. sphere 2. cube 3. cube 4. cube <n><n>### Output: cube <n><n>## Description<n>The Task: Describe a task to solve a problem and provide an appropriate response.<n>* Tasks in this category may require users to perform a complex or extended action, or to navigate complex menus. The response should address the task specified, but also provide useful information to guide the user in performing the task.<n>* The structure is `Task > Response`.<n>* At least one choice will be provided in the task; the user's response must choose one of the choices.<n>* One response will follow the task, in the form of a `question`.<n>* One piece of information may follow the question.<n>* More than one choice may be given for a question, for which the user's response may select at most one of the choices. A choice may follow the response, in the form of `Answer`.<n>* More than one piece of information may follow a response, for which the response's next may contain an array of two to 20 information.<n><n>```javascript<n>const task = 'Write a response that appropriately selects <one or more> of the possible choices.';<n>const choices = 'Choices may include one or more of:';<n><n>const response1 = choices([{'value': 'One', 'text': 'One'}, {'value': 'Two', 'text': 'Two'}, {'value': 'Three', 'text': 'Three'}]);<n>const response2 = choices([{'value' : 'One', 'text' : 'One'},{'value' : 'Two', 'text' : false}]);<n>const response3 = questions([{'type':'short_long'}]);<n>const answer1 = {'value': 'Two'};<n>const answer2 = {'value' : 'One'};<n>```<n><n>Answer 1 Choice: 2<n>Answer 2 Choice: 1<n><n>```javascript<n>function generateTask(context, taskId, taskType, choices, contextTitle, responses, answerChoices = {}) {<n>    let response;<n>    for (
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This may suggest that the task or the process of preparation is of some significance, in order to require that much time each day. Also, the statement "taking 3 hours every morning," implies that he takes the same number of hours each morning (ie. not fluctuating) to complete the task. This further narrows our answer choices.<n><n>- Choice A would not be the best answer, as it does not match the context of the passage. It is unlikely that such a large time commitment would result in "an accident," more likely the subject would suffer severe injuries due to excessive grooming!<n>- Choice C would be the least likely result of 3 hours of preparation each morning, as it would imply that the preparation is a very strenuous or taxing activity that would put the subject at risk of injury.<n>- Choice D would also be unlikely, as there is no context for an upcoming celebration. Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A: murder<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question. <n><n>### Demoscene:In the world of early computer graphics, computer hackers and artists were inventing ways to create new animated effects. Soon a community of people was experimenting with new animation art styles and programs. This community, known as the demoscene, began in 1984 in Sweden with the creation of a computer program. To get a copy of the program the user would have to mail their name and mailing address to a special address. It was in this program that the person would get a screening of their very own movie, created by a software hack called a demo or demo movie. To make your name stand out from everyone else a special name for your computer hacking group was required. The creator named the group Demo or Demo Group. <n><n>After the movie and demonstration, people started to become interested. They began to create their own demo, or demos. The hackers in this community were more than happy to help teach those who wanted to learn. The art style was named after a program created to display new effects called an ASSEMbly. A demo could range from a few minutes to as long as an hour. <n><n>By 1986 there were many democreations in Europe, so democreations began to show their work at demo parties. This was a time period that people would go and show off their creations, have fun watching other people's demos and discuss and help each other. The democreators had a competition to see who could make the most elaborate and creative demo. The winner received a prize. By the early 1990s, there were more than 20 demo parties a year. <n><n>Demos had started to appear on VHS tapes. But still many people wanted to find out more about them, so they would buy cassette tapes of demos, known as demoscene. There was a demo party hosted by The Netherlands called The Party 2. This group made sure every demo cassette tape had three things: <n>* An introduction<n>* Background music (known as intros or music demos)<n>* The demos that the party was known for (e.g. demoscene)<n><n>Towards the end of the 1990’s

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Instruction:Answer the below multiple choice question.<n>#### Demonstration:Input: What do humans take in while _____ing? Choices: A: breathing B: sniffing C: sneezing D: whistling E: harrumphing<n>#### Rationales:1. The question asks us to analyze the context of the given words and figure out the logical conclusion to the sentence.2. The given words are'snitching','sneezing', 'harrumphing', 'lungs', 'diaphragm'. There can only be one correct answer- Snitching is a crime, sneezing is a reaction, harrumphing is a weird sound, and the only body part mentioned is 'lungs' and 'diaphragm' used to breathe. Thus, the correct answer is A: Breathing.<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>A: Breathing

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where is a telephone booth likely to be red? Choices:  A: airport B: gotham city C: london D: city E: gas stations<n><n>### Response:		<n>This is a problem very similar to one seen before, with a few notable distinctions. The problem states we will be looking for a red telephone booth, so we can eliminate possible answers that do not contain this. For instance, the answer choices A-D are all out of the question, as they are referring to telephone booths that are not red — this is also a key hint that we are looking at something related to a city since cities often have a red phonebox, and the answer should either point to a real city or a fictional one.<n><n>The wording “likely” is a key clue to the correct answer, since the idea of a “likely” place to find a red phonebox is to say that it is highly prevalent in that place. We can eliminate the places that don’t fit this. Choices B and C describe fictional cities (Gotham and London), which do not likely have red phoneboxes. Choice D describes real cities, but there are no red phoneboxes in these cities. Also, the only possibility is that a red phonebox is a city feature, not a gas station feature. Thus, the choices we are left with are A (airport) and B (city). However, airports do not have red telephone booths, so we can eliminate it and conclude that the answer is the only choice B—“the city”.<n><n>Answer: B: city<n>

This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:One might find theirs open, with the letters that had been delivered stolen. Choices:  A: front door B: newspaper C: post office D: package E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		<n>This question is related to the previous question above, as it suggests that an item that one receives or delivers through the mail may have been stolen. The item mentioned in question A must be of a type that a thief would specifically target to steal from someone else, which narrows our choices greatly.<n><n>By applying this reasoning to each choice, we can rule out letters (A), post office (C), and package (D), as these would not be something that a thief would target and steal. Similarly, this narrows down our possibilities even further, since newspaper (B) cannot be delivered by mail. The correct answer must then be E: mailbox, as the item would be a package that was delivered to the mailbox.

This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Nowadays people have smart ones, but at one time it was cutting edge to have a tiny calculator on your what? Choices:  A: mobile phone B: wristwatch C: briefcase D: office E: desktop<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B) Wristwatch<n><n>### Explain:<n>This question is asking us to guess the item referred to in the sentence.<n><n>The first clue in this problem is the use of the term "today's people." This points to a trend or custom that exists in general, with no specific person in mind. Another clue is the use of the phrase "at one time."<n><n>The second clue comes from the choice of words in the sentence's clause. "Today's people have..." suggests something that people own now. The word "posession" suggests ownership, and "posession" is often used in the context of one's own home, or office.<n><n>After the question has been posed, more clues are given in the following parts of the sentence. First, the fact that the item was cutting edge to have at the time suggests that it held a high level of status and was desirable.<n><n>Second, it was placed in a container, "the briefcase."<n><n>Third, it was portable, because it was used with something else (the phrase "together").<n><n>The items that can check all those boxes are the "mobile phone," though this may be surprising at first.<n><n>Why would a mobile or cell phone have been cutting-edge? And why would this have been the status symbol back in the day, instead of a smart watch?<n><n>The first question can be answered by a little knowledge of the history of the mobile phone. Initially, the mobile phone was huge and awkward to carry around. Its biggest "problem" was that its battery tended to explode after a few hours of use, and it lacked the ability to play music or store an amazing number of songs.<n><n>The second question can be answered by another factoid from history. In days gone by, some people liked to see how large of a watch they can have. In fact, there were companies that produced watches with very tiny faces and exquisite timepieces.<n><n>Putting the two facts together means that the cutting edge item back then was the mobile phone. <n>

This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the given case, a good answer to this question would be _______________.<n><n>Answer: A: critical thinking<n><n>### Comments<n>1. This question is asking us to explain _something_. We can analyze it piece-by-piece: <n>2. The word "given" means already in possession of. We are to explain what is in possession of the person.<n>3. "Background" refers to their education, skills, experience. This does not need to be a factor if they are given A: critical thinking. Thus, B: congratulations, D: compliments, E: raffle ticket are incorrect.<n>4. The answer does not need to be something that the person receives as well, but a critical aspect that is given to the person (i.e. a skill or knowledge) for the job. Thus, A: critical thinking is correct.<n>

Choices:  A: remember B: help C: count D: winning E: dealing<n><n>### Response:		 B and  E are completely disjoint. Since it’s illegal to count at the casino, it is illegal to win either. But one can play cards with or without an illegal counting system and still win. Hence, the correct response is that it’s illegal to win, and the response is E: dealing.<n><n>### Input A: She was afraid of flying and could not get to her destination. The man on the plane sat next to her and tried to comfort her.<n><n>### Response A:  It’s 100% acceptable to write the story without any “because” in the response. “Because” is a transitional word used as an optional bridge between the introduction and the response.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>Answer the following multiple choice questions. Input: He fantasied of getting a  new car while driving to work and what were the pros and cons of getting a new car<n><n>Demonstration: He fantasied  about getting a  new car  while driving to work and  the pros and cons of  the extra responsibilities  and benefits<n>Rational: We can analyze it piec by piece:  extra responsibilities  suggest an increase in the level  of accountability    or tasks,   what would not arise  from getting a new  car,  experiencing  boredom,  impatience    or pressure.        benefits  often refer to advantageous or  positive results from  something,  and is commonly used in  a work context to refer  to employee benefits.  This narrows our possible  answers down to  something  related to  career  advancement   <n>B and E are disjoint because it is illegal to count cards at a casino,  and  since it is illegal to count at the  casino, it is  illegal to  win  on the card either.    But one  can  play  cards  with or  without  a  illegal counting system    and  win.                                 The correct  response  is that  it is  illegal  to win,  and  the  response  is  E:      deck of cards.<n>The man on the plane sat  next to the woman  without  asking  permission first<n><n>Input A:  She was afraid of flying  and could not get to  her destination<n>Response A:  It’ 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What feeling might propel one to instituting civil action? Choices:  A: complications B: tiredness C: anger D: trial E: court case<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E: court case<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What would you tell ali to do if he bumps into you when you are walking? Choices:  A: work hard B: slow down C: wear shoes D: sell products E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is [B: slow down](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/questions/b-slow-down-6939912093994777480).<n><n>We need to look at the [wording](https://www.perfectwriting.co.uk/blog/article/9621) of the question carefully. "walking" is being used as a metaphor for "living". Ali is the name of a person (who apparently has many fans), therefore, he wouldn't be walking to bump into you, unless it is a [metaphor](https://www.verywellmind.com/what-is-irony-in-literature-1945259) as a means to say that he is doing something, but not doing anything. When you see the word "bumps" or "bubbles" you feel that you may walk into a glass object, or something sharp.<n><n>To make the point clearer, Ali is not a person, but is in fact a "brand". If this was a person, then [this is a [tag:concrete-instruction](https://www.grammarly.com/blog/concrete-instruction/)](https://www.lexico.com/definition/metaphor). Therefore, if Ali bumps into you, you probably will be injured; but a brand does not have physical properties, therefore, "if Ali bump into your" is an [metaphor](http://grammar.yourdictionary.com/grammar-rules-and-tips/grammar-rules/how-to-use-metaphors-in-your-writing-in-the-right-way). <n><n>You can tell someone to slow down while they are living their life, and not hurt you and the other people around them. Therefore, A or D are incorrect because they assume metaphor, but do not consider [grammar](https://www.thefreedictionary.com/grammar): if you are walking, you cannot "sell" products, and Ali is not a person.<n><n>#### Answer:<n>B: slow down<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question, and then move on to the next section.<n><n>### Request:<n>I

The question tells us there are five members in this group. Harry is the only boy the person who always take lead, so C is one of the answer.<n>3. If there are four boys and five members, then one girl in this group. This is contradict with the first sentence. So, only choice B and E are correct.<n>4. Now, John is the name of the group leader. But John also includes John and Tom.<n><n>### Rationale : <n>1. Jack is one of the members, but Jack is not the name of the group, then choice A is correct.<n>2. Lilly, because there was no girl of the name Lily in the story, so choice not B.<n>3. Mary is one of the girls, so choice not D.<n>4. The last sentence says that Tom is the same as John and Tom, so choice B and E is correct.<n><n>Answer: A: John<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The family was playing cards, what would be a reason for this? Choices:  A: amusement B: losing money C: charmed D: having fun E: win money<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: amusement<n><n>### Demeter:<n>1. This phrase suggests that there is a family playing cards, so we can expect something related to the family. Amusement is typically a pastime for a family to spend time together and can be used to refer to a variety of activities. Since the context has been established, this is our correct answer.<n>2. The clues are very vague for what the "cards" are, and while technically we could choose any of the given options, these all seem rather unlikely for family entertainment. There are no mentions of money, so this answer can be ruled out.<n>3. This question also contains the word "losing", which means there could be something lost involved in this activity, but we can tell that it is not money and it is not implied, so we can safely rule this answer out. We also can't use the word "win", as cards being used for betting seems to out of place for the context.<n>4. This phrase, as well as the word "win", could also refer to victory. But since the card-playing is something the family is doing together, this is probably not what we are looking for, as they likely would play cards in their households.<n>5. As a result, the only answer left is the most likely one, amusement, which means we should select A.<n><n><!--### Conclusion and Review:<n> 1. We can answer a question when given a specific input and the answer must be correct based on the given context.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>2. Practice making your own questions and answers.<n><n>### Bonus:<n>3. See if the instructions were the same for the answers.<n><n>## Learn more:<n><n> 1. [Quora](https://www.quora.com/).<n><n> 2. Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question provides some clues as to why not enough chairs were available for everyone. Given that the building had a coffeehouse and an office, it's not obvious what might be delayed: perhaps no one's job could be done because there weren't enough meeting rooms, or perhaps there weren't sufficient coffee purchases to offset the overhead and allow for the coffeehouse to remain open. However, there is also a possibility that the delay could result from the activity happening at another location. For example, if the building had a bookstore, there would likely be a large number of potential customers who might have attended the meeting instead. So, the correct answer here would be D: office.<n><n>### Input :  A man said "No hard feeling" to his supervisor at the end of the workday.  From this sentence, what was this man's relationship with his supervisor on a scale from 1-5, with 1 = least favorable? Choices: 1-3: 0.0-1.99, and  4-5: 2.0-4.99, Choices: A: 0.0 B: 1.0 C: 1.99 D: 2.0 E: 3.33 F: 4.0 G: 4.5 H: 5.0<n><n>### Response<n>First, it should be noted that there are two questions in this problem. The man was talking about his relationship with his supervisor and the word "with" in the question refers to that relationship. Next, we see that the scale is from 0 to 5, with 0 being the least favorable, and 5 being the most favorable. Finally, from the text we know that the man was talking to his supervisor and that he was saying good-bye at the end of the day. Using this information, the most clear answer would be D: good feelings.<n><n>A would be too little to be favorable, B is the least favorable, C is too close to 2 for a reasonable answer, D expresses that the feelings were good, but they could be either friendly or professional, and F is unreasonably high. <n><n>If the questioner is talking about two entities, then E and G are the only other real options. It is only natural to assume that a person using this scale would

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: feeble B: bullbleep C: cow D: female E: charging prey<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is b.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>This is a little harder than the previous problem, the instruction itself is more open-ended then the last, and also contains more clues for the user to take advantage of.<n><n>The instruction first states that a character "called bull" when his friend said that it is "feeble" to call a bull what. This phrasing is extremely vague, as "feeble" doesn't mean what it says literally. Therefore, the first clue we have to take into account is that the character did not agree with this assessment. The friend's suggestion is to call a bull "feeble" which is a strange request and makes us think the friend's suggestion was meant to be a joke. We can also reasonably assume that the friend's assessment of feeble is to say that it is useless or has no meaning.<n><n>The second clue is in the instruction itself, which mentions that the object of the friend's insult was a bull (and not, for example, some other animal), and that it was insulted. We can also infer that the bull was not "charging prey" at that point in time for no good reason, nor was it female, and also not a cow.<n><n>Another clue is the friend referring to the animal as "bull," which may be a typo, or it can be an indication that whatever the friend was saying, it was obviously connected to the concept of a bull.<n><n>The question asks, "what is a bull?" This is quite vague. The instruction itself provides some more context, by mentioning that the subject of this question is someone who "called bull," which is referring to the same character as the subject in the question. Thus, we can narrow our scope to that friend only. We also have the two clues that the friend is calling whatever is being insulted feeble, and it is obviously connected to the concept bull. There is no evidence as to why the friend is insulting the bull, but it appears to be something unrelated to its gender, its status, its charges, or any of the other characteristics that the answer options allude to.<n><n>After taking these cues into account, the first answer that appears to logically be ruled out (since it is a word that pertains to its gender)

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where would there be a connection to go to another place? Choices:  A: wires B: electrical circuit C: computer network D: wall E: freeway<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: wall<n><n>### Demostration:<n>A:<n>Rationales:<n>1. The sentence contains the clue "where would there be a connection?"<n>2. The subject is a place, so the context must be geographical.<n>3. Electrical circuits and freeways need to be connected to other places or they can't exist, so none of these answers make sense.<n>4. "Wires" do not make sense either; wires are physical objects that connect electrical circuits. They do not go anywhere, they aren't physical places where something *else* exists, so they don't make sense in the context.<n>5. "Computer netowrks" refer to an interconnection of computers, and can only be used if there is a computer present, so they do not make sense in this scenario.<n>6. "wall" refers to a physical barrier, and this is clearly what the question is asking. Therefore the answer is "wall".

We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:A shark swam in the background aquarium as the card players sat emotionless, what were they playing? Choices: A: call the teacher B: correct the teacher C: ignore the teacher D: leave the class E: explain why it is impossible to get homework<n><n>### Response<n>Rationales:<n><n>Rationale: 1. The first line provides the context that it is about a student's homework.<n><n><n>2. Context: The next three sentence fragments provide three types of responses the student could have to her/his teacher telling them that they could not complete the assignment. These responses are a call to the teacher to discuss the assignment further, an assurance that they will complete it, and a reason why it cannot be done.<n><n><n>3. Logic: Given this context and the clues provided, all logical responses would either involve a call or an assurance that s/he was working on the assignment, as leaving the class would be an impolite response, and a teacher who tells the child that it is impossible to get the work done would likely be the last person who would want to hear an assurance or an assurance that the assignment was not possible.<n><n>Hence, the only logical answer choice must be either a call to the teacher or a statement that the student will complete the homework regardless. <n>Answer: D: tell my teacher why it is impossible to complete the homework (if you think that they are telling her/him to tell them that there was a problem with their assignment, or that they should tell her/him that they were not going to do the work, and the statement can be considered an assurance in that sense.)<n><n>### Input Do you think it really worth spending almost 10k on some new shoe?<n><n>### Response <n>Input Do you __________ spending almost 1,00? Choices:  A: station B: every car and house C: shop D: bedroom E: space shuttle<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstration:<n>We can discern a few things from this:<n><n>1. A person who wants to buy a specific product "wants" to or "is seeking" that product.<n>2. That product would be a product that they "want" or are seeking for their own consumption.<n>3. The buyer "wants" this product when they "go" or seek this product out.<n>4. Therefore, the consumer would be somewhere "they" could go to buy a product they "want".<n>5. Therefore, the consumer wants to or is looking to buy it somewhere where they can go.<n>6. The radio is "something" and can be "bought" from a certain location.<n>7. Therefore, the consumer is looking to go someplace where they can buy a radio - the radio store.<n>Hence, the most logical place to "buy a radio" would be "the store" or a "radio store".<n><n>Answer: B: the store<n><n>### Response Analysis:<n>Through the given context clues and hints in the problem, our conclusion about the correct answer choice is that a person is "looking to" buy something, and there are various places where they might do this. The answer choice "the store" makes the most sense because this is a well known location frequented by people looking to buy things. Therefore it would be the most logical choice.<n><n>### Input - A: When is a company's best time to make capital expenditures? Choices: <n>A: After a bull market B: During a bull market C: Before a bear market D: After a bear market E: None of the above<n><n>The best investment in a long term bear market is cash.<n>The best use of cash is to make investments in a long term bull market.<n>It is better to be long than to be wrong in the long term. This means that if the stock market goes bearish then it is a good time to buy stocks because the price will be low, and it is a good time for a business to invest in itself because the price of capital goods will be low. <n>Cash is a safe investment during a time of high returns in the stock market because the returns will be low and the risk is limited. Hence a capital expenditure during a bull market offers a higher return on

Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The artist knew that this was the peak of his fandom, so he decided it was time for cashing in by doing what? Choices:  A: selling out B: happy C: fishing D: receiving money E: getting paid<n><n>### Response:		 B: happy<br>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. By using the word 'paper', the writer may be trying to get us to rule out anything that stores electronic files--the obvious answer would seem to be 'computer', but the writer wants to be sure to include 'computers' but exclude 'computers'.<n>

Choices:  A: restorand B: wedding party C: church basement D: corridor E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		<n>There is no "center table" at a reception, since the reception itself consists of a variety of tables. Hence, the "centermost table" at a reception would actually be the "center table," implying "the main table at a party," or "the biggest and central table." Given that a reception is usually centered around food, the correct answer would be A: restorand, and the answer is C.<n><n>### Input He is running for class president. Choices: A: president B: vp C: reelection D: commitee E: candidate<n><n>### Response He is running for reelection, since that is the only position explicitly associated with a candidate while running a campaign (and not that for class president). Since reelection candidates are often considered more established and mature than those running for the first time, the answer is E: candidate.<n>

Choices:  A: open letter B: thank god C: say goodbye D: bless you E: listen to radio<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The answer to this question is "C: say goodbye." When someone finishes a conversation with someone (usually in person or over the phone) they typically say something to indicate that the conversation is ending, such as "thank you for calling," "thank you for coming by," or "thank you for your time." Saying goodbye, particularly if the conversation is short, is appropriate and respectful.<n><n>Answer: C: say goodbye

Choices:  A: wooded area B: body of water C: the ocean D: british columbia E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>![Response](../Screenshot/S01E01.png)<n><n>### Answer:<n>A: Wooded area is the only feasible answer.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>- A:  Wooded area is the literal location where they live.<n>- B:  Water is a different topic, the beaver can live in a body of water but not a beaver.<n>- C: There is no ocean here. This is a very common answer choice but is just plain wrong.<n>- D: This is the country of Canada. That makes the question and answer more like this: *Where in Canada does a beaver leave*?<n>- E: The beaver stays in a zoo, not leaves<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>import pandas as pd <n>import regex <n>from typing import Optional <n>from collections import Counter<n>import requests<n><n><n>def clean_data():<n>    response = requests.get('http://www.answers.com/Q/Where_does_a_beaver_live_and_leave').text<n>    response = re.sub(r'[\r\n]','',' '.join(response.split('\n')), regex=r'([a-z]+):\.answers\.com\/question/([^ \r\n]+).*Where\sin\s([\w\d\s-]+)*') # Remove the.answers.[com]/ and.answers.[com] as they are just fluff for SEO  <n>    return response<n><n><n>def get_answer(question, response):<n>    cleanedResponse = re.sub(ur"{}(?=\s[a-z])".format(question), lambda x: f"\1" + x.groups()[0], response) # Remove the part after the word after the? as this is a literal "that is why" part<n>    resultList = re.finditer(ur"[a-z]:\s[a-z]", cleanedResponse)<n>    questions = [res[1].lower().split(' ')[0] for res in resultList if'' + res[1].lower().rstrip(':') in Counter(resultList[0].lower())]<n>    choice = [f'{x.rstrip(":")}' for x in questions
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:It had a beach with shallow water, while not the ocean this was a hot spot all the locals enjoyed on the what? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: pond C: lake D: bathe in E: childrens pool<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E: children's pool.<n>

The man booked the robber in car.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>1. **Police** – indicates he was a police officer, not a thief, robber or car driver.<n>2. **man** – a male<n>3. **police man** – a male police officer or a police constable<n>4. **was waving flares** – The police man was waving in vain<n>5. Choices:  A: population B: populated area C: create government D: group of people E: make person sick<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question states that there are certain "spacies" without which our existence is impossible. We can narrow down possible answers using this rule of thumb: "There cannot be 'x' without 'y'". Using this principle leads us to a shortlist of only possible options that still apply:<n><n>- Population: "There cannot be people without number of people"<n>- Government: "There cannot be a government without... governed people"<n>- Sickness: "There cannot be sickness without... healthy people?"<n><n>Based on the question, it seems like both population and government are too wide-reaching and unlikely, leading us to the answer of "sickness".

This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What do all humans have on the side of their head? Choices:  A: two feet B: two ears C: horns D: lay eggs E: one head<n><n>### Response:		D: Lay eggs This one was pretty quick and obvious.<n><n>Rationales: the word "all" would suggest "every human" which means none of them have two feet and/or two ears, making answer choices A and C impossible. I think the real hint to this one is "side of the head" which has a particular ring to it in humans that may be a red herring but isn't helpful to an alien. It means that no human has horns or lays eggs because those appendages are almost certainly going to be on the other side of their body where they can clearly see them.<n>

Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question asks us whether or not we should walk barefoot after it’s rained, and provides some information as to the reasons for caution: the ground is wet, clothes are wet, and we might fall. However, the question omits a vital piece of information: water.<n><n>We can logically deduce that water, more specifically, the rain, is the reason not to walk barefoot after the rain. Why? If we’re walking after a rainfall, we will almost certainly be walking in puddles of water, which could be slippery, so what are more common reasons not to walk barefoot in the rain is the water in our clothes and on the wet ground.<n><n>Since the question provides the information to us and the reasons we should not walk barefoot are so logical and common sense, the answer should instead be "A: shoes."<n><n>Answer: A: shoes<n><n>### Input He was a what that went on many errands in his horse-drawn carriage and was quite a hero in the community?<n><n>### Response The question is asking us what the man was with a somewhat cryptic hint, referring to people who go on errands and are heroes in the community, i.e. a "horse-drawn carriage" and "errands" are usually associated with historical time periods and the question implies someone in a relatively prominent position in town, so we have to think:<n><n>There are many possible answers, but we’d want to eliminate anything that would be a bit far-fetched such as "lighthouse-keeper" or "lamp-lighter."<n><n>Finding a historical connection would be helpful, for example, the phrasing "horse-drawed carriage" makes us think of the late 18th to early 20th century, so we can eliminate any time pre-1900.<n><n>The phrase in question is really important, as it is a hint. "Hero in the community" is another hint: it’s probably an important person in the community, and hero in our time is a bit different than hero in the community so what was a hero for the community during that time?<n><n>In terms of being quests, we’d need to be someone of importance to warrant the time, so maybe a judge or mayor? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where can you get in shape and drink at a juice bar? Choices:  A: fridge B: limejuice C: square D: gym E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Where can you get in shape in drink at a juice  bar?<n><n>### Instructions: Use context on the problem to answer the next question.<n><n>## Demonstration: If the fridge were being cleaned out, then it could mean that the fridge  would be emptied out, which would mean that it would have things in it. If<n> there were no things in fridge, it would be empty.<n><n>## Rationale: Since you have nothing or nothing else, it can be concluded that it is not full, which means the most logical answer is A: limejuice, so the correct answer is A: limes<n><n>## Alternative analysis<n><n>This problem can be analysed several other ways. For example, one could first realize that the fridge needs to be cleaned out because there is something in it but not a lot, making it most likely a juice or a bar. This kind of analysis is not recommended since the reasoning is far too simplistic and may lead to mistakes.<n><n>## Multiple choice questions<n><n>We’ve discussed a simple, single-question question. However, multiple choice questions also make use of context clues.<n><n><n>## Context clue examples<n><n>The best way to find context clues is by looking at where the context comes on the page. If the context comes after a description or before a definition, it is probably a definition of the given term. If it is an explanation for something that you are expected to already know, it is probably a synonym for that term. If it is a follow-up, it is most likely asking what you would do in that situation.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Input: Who is my best friend? Choices: 1) A: Mike 2) B: Tim 3) C: Jim 4) D: Kyle<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>From the question, you can tell that the best friend is one you should already know and not a new one. The word 'best' implies not only a preference for the given term but also that the given term is more or less important than the other terms. If the other terms are also best friends of yours, then you can rule out B and C, making it the most logical answer D, which is true if you are a middle-schooler for whom this question might be asked. A similar context-based inference technique

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What does exercising immediately lead to? Choices:  A: relaxation B: exhaustion C: energetic D: become stronger E: use energy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>>Exercise or physical training for health or competition purposes is a frequently encountered topic in the Analytical Writing section of the GRE, often in the form of an argument for or against exercising.<n><n>### It's important to know the common arguments used in the issue paragraph from the example below.<n>In addition, we want you to be aware of several clues that point to the correct response.<n><n>### Exercise: Choose the most appropriate response<n><n>Answer: Option B, exhaustion.<n><n>### Input:"Working out at the gym is only good if you use the time for self-reflection." Analyze the argument below.<n><n>### The argument makes a claim, identifies a flaw in its logic, and attempts to remedy the flaw by addressing the claim in a different way. The conclusion should address the issue identified in the argument.<n><n>### Here is a general example if you aren't certain what an argument with a flaw looks like.<n><n>### Answer: This sentence is a poor argument. The premise, if true, would be a sufficient reason to go to the gym, but it is not clear why it is relevant to the issue of self-reflection. The conclusion does not make an argument from this premise. A better argument would be, "Going to the gym enables you to focus on self-reflection, so it is important to go to the gymn regardless of other activities that will distract you while exercising like other forms of stress management and relaxation." Self-reflection is the logical result of the exercise rather than the only beneficial result.<n><n>### 1st Source<n><n>### The sentence below states a claim and provides two reasons to support it.<n><n>### Analysis: The argument depends on the meaning of "enough" and "a lot" and what it means to "run on the treadmill" and "eat the bagel."<n><n>### You also need to be aware of "implicit premises." For instance, we know from the passage that the subject would have had "plenty of time" if exercise had not been so difficult.<n><n>### A conclusion should address the logical flaw or gap in the previously presented arguments.<n><n>### An effective conclusion does not depend on the original argument.<n><n>It is important to

The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where do you wait in a reception area for a meeting? Choices:  A: hall B: motel C: hotels D: law firm E: office building<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is C: Hotel<n>Input: Where do you wait in a... A: reception area B: motel C...<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The clues in the prompt suggest that the subject is waiting in for a meeting, which is usually done at a work-related location (i.e. a hotel or airport, or office building).<n><n>The answers A and B are clearly wrong, leaving us with only the remaining answer options or C, D, and E. However, A is clearly negated, as we are told that we are waiting in a "reception area" and nothing in the definition of reception area as described in the dictionary suggests that one has to be staying there. Option D is also ruled out, as a "law firm" is not a location where one would wait, and option E is ruled out by context, as the preceding sentence states that the subject is waiting for a meeting, for which an office building would also not be a reasonable place.<n><n>The only remaining option is therefore C: the hotel, which fits exactly into the context of the prompt and also corresponds to the definition of reception areas given in the dictionary.<n><n>### Input Where did your grandparents take a group selfie using their smartphone and what happened that the group selfie was ruined?<n><n>### Response Where did your... A: uncle B: aunt C: grandfather D: daughter E: grandmother<n><n>### Exploration:<n>The first part of the sentence tells us that the subjects are talking about their grandparents. One would assume that they are using their phones to send photos to each other. The second part tells us that the group selfie has been ruined, which could mean that the grandparents attempted to take a group photo and either the group disbanded, were unable to take the photo, or did not save the photo.<n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer to this question would be C, E. Only these options describe the grandparents as having taken a group selfie and the photo as being ruined.<n>A, B and D describe the grandparent taking a standard photo and the grandchildren not ruining the photo. As such, it would have worked too, but this is not what the question was asking for.<n><n>### Exclusion<n><n>### Exclude:<n>

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Rewrite a question from the problem.<n><n><n>### Reworded Problem:<n>He fantasied about getting what while driving to work, and the pros and cons were of the additional responsibilities and benefits of his job? His decision to get a car had pros (b) and cons(period) (of the responsibilities and benefits).<n><n>### Sentences 2 Restatement:<n><n>### Sentense 3 Restatement:<n>### Sentence Conclusion:<n>His decision (to get a car) had pros and cons of responsibilities and benefits(period).<n><n>### Question Restatement<n>What was the subject that he fantasied about? Choices:  a car, a promotion, boredom and pressure.<n><n><n>This is the end of the assignment of this task. Thank you for your cooperation and I'll see with you in the next exercise.<n>

Answer Choices: A: snake B: caterpillar C: earthworm D: ant E: grasshopper F: toothless lizard G: toothed lizard<n><n>### Demostration and Rationales:<n>This problem contains many hints that can help us determine what the correct answer is. Firstly, we are told that a good rule of thumb is that if the first two words are "A..." and "B..." (the first letters of the three choices) then the third option must be "C...", which is not the case with the choices given. This means that the third option must be the opposite of the other two choices, making "the other..." the correct answer.<n>Moreover, we are told that A is a snake (as the "first" option), B is an ant (as the third option)  and C is a caterpillar. This confirms that the opposite of a snake and an ant is a caterpiller and the first choice must be a caterpillars. Finally, we are told that caterpillars let the first what go and rest when it is done. This suggests that the previous options were snake and ant and that the first one should be caterpillar, the second snake and the third Ant.<n>Therefore, according to the clues given, the correct option would be C: caterpillars, as they let the first what go (they eat the leaf) and they rest when they are done with the leaf. Answer: C: Caterpillars<n><n>### Response :<n>Input:<n>A good rule of thumb:<n>- The first whats go by and let it lay when it's done<n>-<n>The answer choices:<n>- A: toothed l

Choices:  A: lake B: manhattan C: shoreline D: coastal area E: los angeles<n><n>### Response:		A bay is a body of water that is partly surrounded by land but not completely enclosed. Therefore, a bay is always found by a lake, manhattan, shoreline, coastal area, or los angeles.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		What were Bill's physical symptoms when he first woke and in the morning?<n>Bill was fatigued.<n><n>### Input:[I have trouble falling asleep](D) but once I do, the trouble staying asleep the next night. Choices: A: I'm not as anxious about going to sleep as I was yesterday. B: I usually need to set an alarm C: I get to sleep without help D: I'm less rested the next day E: I awake earlier the next morning.<n><n>### Response:[My insomnia has gotten better and now I set the alarm](E) because I am tired more often the next morning.<n>

Fungus is a type of fungi(plural) so that tells me that something made from milk would be food. The question has food in it so it must be about food.<n><n>### Input:"Which was a more fun way to travel?"Choices: A: riding a bike with panniers B: hiking with nothing C: walking on a beach D: flying a balloon E: all of them<n><n>### Response<n>The answer is the "balloon."<n>I know that "panniers" are type of bags attached to bikes. The only type of travel that is in those types of baggage is bicycle riding. Balloons cannot carry baggage so the balloon is not in that category. As you go to the beach walking, you don't have to carry anything except for swimsuits and other necessities for traveling. So walking is "all of them."<n># A: riding a bicycle<n><n># B: hiking<n><n># C: walking on the beach<n><n># D: flying a balo<n><n># E: all of them #All of them.<n><n>### Additional examples are described below:<n><n>### Instructions: The correct answers to the following multiple-choice questions can be found below the question.<n><n>#### Instruction:"Who is the only person in the city who can drive a bike in a parking lot with cars?" Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A: tenacity.<n><n>### Rationales: 1-He set the cup on the floor.  The ground is not the correct choice because it has both nouns and an article in it.<n><n>2- The second sentence of the passage tells us that it did not matter because the man has what it takes.  The man was very determined to set the cup on the ground because he picked a coater to set the cup on.  The man also did it without any other support.<n><n>3- The man had the coaster, and the coaster had the cup.  There must be a noun with a meaning that has in common with coaster; to hold.
